comments.content: As I had trouble finding how this was done, i google for the ADM paging part and found this URL to find the above answer is the right one: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/firepower/ftd-api/guide/ftd-rest-api/ftd-api-methods.html#task_C0F2D4C92FF64354A972D205BD4A0B3D

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

Drag and drop the code from the bottom onto the box where the code is missing to list objects that use the paginated Cisco FDM API. Some options may be used more than once. Not all options are used.

//IMG//
What is a characteristic of a monolithic architecture?

choices.B: New capabilities are deployed by restarting a component of the application.
choices.A: It is an application with multiple independent parts.
choices.C: A service failure can bring down the whole application.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct.
monolithic design - issues with the traditional 
- Scaling vertically, easy but limited. Scaling horizontal required add logical redesign.
- Tightly coupled - Maintenance is hard
- Single development stack (you will be stuck using the same technology for all) and because of this the answer D is wrong related to the COMPONENTS. 
> Best scenario is to use a loose coupling design to be split up into independent services.
C is obviously the most correct, but monolithic versus microservice, has nothing to do with beinf platform specific. Badly built question.

C is the correct answer. A monolitic app can be platform-agnostic but it's not mandatory. But is the app is monolitic, a service failure (such as storage or network) will bring down the whole app/service.
This is unlike the distributed application architecture where failure of one microcomponent can be detected and fixed dynamically.

questions.question_text: How is an OAuth2 three-legged authentication flow initiated?

choices.A: Construct an API call to retrieve the credentials.
choices.D: Exchange the key for an access token.
choices.B: The user makes a request to the OAuth client.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
- The user makes a request to the OAuth client.

 https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/datapower-gateway/2018.4?topic=flows-three-legged-oauth-flow

Selected Answer: A
A correct no-store is for disabling cache because there is sensitive information
B no since it's not in request field but response
C. no - can be cached
D. no - only client can cache but the question mentions it could be sensitive data

questions.question_text:
A web application has these requirements for HTTP cache control:

• The client browser must be prevented from storing responses that contain sensitive information.
• Assets must be downloaded from the remote server every time.

Which header must the engineer use?

discussion.content: i would change last 2 between them, first bulletinNumber and then reason

comments.content: yes you are right, because f-String is used in the print statement

discussion.content:
I am not sure...

?customerId= - correct
&rows=10 - correct
res.bulletinNumber - as human readable 
{res.bulletinNumber} - as answer received

For example answer can be "Bulletin#: res.bulletinNumber, 55564"

{res.Reason} - incorrect because where are no such response parametr, only - bulletinNumber
may be res.Reason, but ...
"Bulletin#: res.Reason, 55564"
It looks as no one code snippets absent

comments.content: also, they should be in curly braces

Also it should be `res.vulnerabilityReason` not `res.Reason`, maybe that's a typo?
